info.game_comments:
2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 11.
Single-player Final Jeopardy!

(1, 1).clue: This totally darkened phase of the Moon occurs when the Moon is between the Sun & the Earth

(3, 1).clue: He presided over the Senate in the first Congress

(4, 1).clue: In the 1970s the organization NOW made the passage of this its top priority

(5, 1).clue: Some folks from Scotland are Highlanders, while some people from this country are Shanghailanders

(6, 1).clue: Meaning to be prepared, it refers to having your canvasbacks strung
(6, 1).correct response: get your ducks in a row

(1, 2).clue: In August 1609 he demonstrated his newly constructed telescope to the Senate of Venice, who then doubled his salary

(3, 2).clue: The Liberty Bell weighs about a ton; this similarly named bell in Charlotte, N.C. weighs 7 tons

(4, 2).clue: On Aug. 4, 1972 Arthur Bremer was sentenced to 63 years in prison for shooting this governor

(5, 2).clue: The people of this British dependency are sometimes known as Onions for short--or is that for shorts?

(6, 2).clue: To complain like a reddish-brown game bird with feathered feet & legs

(1, 3).clue: When "shadow bands" are seen on Earth, it means this is about to happen up in the heavens

(3, 3).clue: Nimitz' line "Uncommon valor was a common virtue" was about the World War II battle for this island

(4, 3).clue: In 1978 robbers stole $6 million in cash & jewelry from Lufthansa Airlines at this U.S. airport

(5, 3).clue: A Manchegan is a "man of" this Spanish region

(6, 3).clue: Hard, shrewd bargaining, like negotiating for an Appaloosa

(1, 4).clue: In ancient times, this star rose at dawn during the hottest time of summer, thus the "dog days of summer"

(3, 4).clue: Following 1912, it was the next year a star was added to the U.S. flag

(4, 4).clue: Officially, these '75 "Accords" were the final act of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe

(5, 4).clue: The people of this Aussie state have an ap"peel"ing nickname: Apple Islanders

(6, 4).clue: To create different words, this prefix can go before berry, neck & flesh

(1, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from beside a replica rover at the Adler Planetarium in Chicago, IL.)  This is a replica of both the Mars exploration rover Spirit and this companion, who came knocking in January 2004

(3, 5).clue: Robert Mills designed this structure that opened in 1888 & was built from 36,491 blocks

(4, 5).clue: This Army doctor convicted of the 1970 murder of his wife & family insisted that drug-crazed hippies did it

(5, 5).clue: This British city's Medieval Latin name was Cantabrigia, so its people are Cantabrigians

(6, 5).clue: This verb means to hesitate in confusion like a bottom-feeding fish

(1, 1).clue: Delaware's deed, given to William Penn in 1682, resides in the Hall of Records in this Capitol

(3, 1).clue: She got a B.A. from Cornell in 1960 & an LL.B. from Harvard Law School in 1963

(4, 1).clue: Also known as the Sacco chair, it was designed by Zanotta of Milan & featured a bag filled with plastic beads

(5, 1).clue: In a Shakespeare play, Mamillius says, "A sad tale's best for" this season

(6, 1).clue: "Ugliness was the one reality", muses this Oscar Wilde title character

(1, 2).clue: The name of this capital is another word for God's guidance

(2, 2).clue: 1979:"Welcome to 2 hours of sparkling entertainment spread out over a 4-hour show"

(3, 2).clue: This American journalist was embedded inPetrograd in 1917 during the "10 Days that Shook the World"

(4, 2).clue: Empire, the first major style of the 1800s, originated in this country during its First Empire, 1804-1814

(5, 2).clue: The existential statement "Hell is other people" comes from this play

(6, 2).clue: This 1858 work was a landmark in its use of medical illustrations of the human body

(1, 3).clue: The homes of Mark Twain & Harriet Beecher Stowe can be found in this state capital

(2, 3).clue: 1968:"Welcome to the Academy Awards, or, as it's known at my house, Passover"

(3, 3).clue: He's seen here performing in one of his own works

(4, 3).clue: From a Latin word for "read", it's a slanted-top stand used to support a speaker's notes

(5, 3).clue: Besides "Cyrano de Bergerac", his best-remembered play is the patriotic tragedy "The Eaglet"

(6, 3).clue: On Oct. 7, 2003 Arnold terminated this man's stay in the governor's mansion

(1, 4).clue: The Old Barracks Museum in this capital was the location of a major turning point in the Revolutionary War

(2, 4).clue: 2003:"It was so sweet backstage, you should see it.  The Teamsters are helping Michael Moore into the trunk of his limo"

(3, 4).clue: This portraitist was born in Devon on July 16, 1723

(4, 4).clue: From the French for "scaffold", it's a stand resembling a scaffold that has open shelves used for small curios

(5, 4).clue: 1949 play character who says, "Charley is... liked, but he's not--well liked"

(6, 4).clue: Sciurus carolinensis, it pretty much always feels like a nut

(1, 5).clue: A planetarium in this capital bears the name of Christa McAuliffe, who died in the 1986 Challenger explosion

(2, 5).clue: 1974: "Just think, the only laugh that man will probably ever get is for stripping and showing off his shortcomings"

(3, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from a street in the Lower East Side, New York.)  This reformer & photographer described the conditions of the Lower East Side in 1890's "How the Other Half Lives"

(4, 5).clue: This English furniture designer who followed Chippendale wrote his "Cabinet-Maker and Upholsterer's Guide" in 1788

(5, 5).clue: As the title implies, this play features an important arrival, that of Hickey in the saloon

(6, 5).clue: In the 1870s he invented elements of a telephone-like device

(0, 0).clue: In 2000 this writer, with more than 100 million copies of novels in print, had a new species of dinosaur named for him
